Chairman Grothman, Ranking Member Garcia, distinguished members of the House Oversight Subcommittee on National Security, Representative Burchett and Luna.
My name is Ryan Fobs Graves and I'm a former F18 pilot with a Decade of Service in the U.S. Navy,
including two deployments in Operation Enduring Freedom and Operation Inherent Resolve.
I have experienced advanced UAP firsthand and I'm here to voice the concerns of more than 30 commercial aircrew and military veterans who have confided their similar encounters with me.
Today, I would like to highlight three critical issues that demand our action.
As we convene here, UAP are in our airspace, but they are grossly underreported.
These sightings are not rare or isolated. They are routine.
Military aircrew and commercial pilots, trained observers whose lives depend on accurate identification, are frequently witnessing these phenomena.

and is only compounded by recent government claims questioning the credibility of eyewitness testimony.
Parts of our government are aware of more about UAP than they let on, but excessive classification practices keep crucial information hidden.

After upgrades were made to our jet's radar systems, we began detecting unknown objects operating in our airspace.
At first, we assumed they were radar errors, but soon we began to correlate the radar tracks with multiple onboard sensors, including infrared systems, eventually through visual ID.
During a training mission in the warning area of Whiskey 72, ten miles off the coast of Virginia Beach, two F18 Super Hornets were split by UAP.
The object, described as a dark gray or a black cube inside of a clear sphere, came within 50 feet of the lead aircraft and was estimated to be 5 to 15 feet in diameter.
The mission commander terminated the flight immediately and returned base.
Our squadron submitted a safety report, but there was no official acknowledgment of the incident and no further mechanism to report the sightings.

Lt. Ryan Graves begins by introducing himself as an F/A-18 Super Hornet pilot with over 3,500 hours of flight experience. He served in the US Navy for nine years before retiring in 2017. During his service, he was stationed at NAS Lemoore, CA, where he flew with VFA-106 "Gladiators" from 2004 to 2009.

He then describes an incident that occurred during one of their training missions near San Diego, California, involving a Tic Tac-shaped object moving at high speed and performing maneuvers far beyond what any known aircraft could do. The object rapidly accelerated in front of them and disappeared within seconds. This event lasted around half a mile but left no physical evidence behind.

Lt. Graves mentions that they immediately turned back to see where the whitewater (the ocean's surface) was located after losing contact with it, only to find out that it had also vanished along with the mysterious object. They returned to base and shared their encounter with other pilots who were getting ready to launch, including Alex Detrick - another witness present today.

After returning home, Lt. Graves learned about Jay Stratton through social media connections; Mr. Stratton is part of ATIP program led by Lou Elizondo in Pentagon. In 2009, Lt. Graves received information regarding active jamming on APG-73 radar systems caused by the UAP he encountered earlier. However, this information has never been released publicly or investigated further.

In 2017, when Tom DeLonge formed To The Stars Academy alongside former government officials like Louis Elizondo, Chris Mellon, Steve Justice, Helene Cooper, Rob Blumenthal, and Leslie Kean, Lt. Graves decided to come forward as one of the first military whistleblowers speaking openly about his experience with unidentified aerial phenomena (UAP). This decision came after being approached by both Mr. Elizondo and Tom DeLonge separately.

Since then, more witnesses have come forward sharing similar experiences involving advanced technology not from Earth that defies our current understanding of physics and engineering principles. These testimonies highlight the need for oversight over any work done using taxpayer funds related to these mysterious crafts - even if they are classified under an "unacknowledged wave" program within the US Government.

Finally, Lt. Graves emphasizes the importance of ensuring proper checks and balances in place across all government programs dealing with extraterrestrial life forms or technologies so that elected representatives can adequately serve their constituents' interests while protecting national security concerns at the same time.

4 witnesses are being questioned by Congressman Garcia regarding their experiences with unidentified aerial phenomena (UAP). The purpose of the hearing is to better understand how pilots interact with UAPs and what steps should be taken for national security purposes.

The first witness, Mr. Fravor, explains his encounter with a Tic-Tac shaped object while flying an F/A-18 fighter jet off the coast of San Diego in 2004. He describes seeing the object hovering at around 35,000 feet before descending rapidly towards him. When he got closer, he noticed no visible engines or exhaust plumes but could see details such as windows and portholes. After circling the object several times, they lost visual contact due to cloud cover.

Mr. Graves then shares his experience from 2019 when he was flying over New Jersey on a commercial airliner. He saw two bright lights moving erratically near each other, which eventually merged into one larger light that followed them for about 10 minutes before disappearing suddenly. This event lasted approximately 2 hours and involved multiple aircraft including military jets trying to intercept it without success.

Mrs. Bigelow discusses her work on developing advanced materials and sensors used by NASA's space program. She states that there is evidence suggesting some UAPs may have originated from Earth rather than extraterrestrial sources, citing examples like balloons or drones being mistaken for alien craft. However, she also acknowledges that many cases remain unexplained and more research needs to be done.

Finally, Mr. Grush raises concerns about information being hidden within the intelligence community regarding UAP encounters. answer:
4 former military personnel were asked questions about their experiences with unidentified aerial phenomena (UAP) during their time serving in the US Air Force. The witnesses agreed that misdirection by official US government agencies exists regarding UAPs and that they are having an impact on our training ranges. They also stated that these incidents should not be treated as a legitimate issue.

When questioned about specific instances around Phoenix Valley, such as the famous Phoenix Light case from '97, all four witnesses expressed ignorance beyond what is publicly known about those lights. However, when asked where Congress could find files and who they would address if they wanted further information, one witness offered a "vector" but did not provide details. This suggests that there may still be classified information surrounding these events which cannot be disclosed without proper authorization.

The witnesses discussed steps Congress can take to address training range impacts due to UAPs. One suggestion was for each service branch to implement a reporting mechanism similar to the Navy's range-fourer report, which gathers information from pilots. Another recommendation included attaching sensor data to reports and creating systems capable of handling multiple classification levels of data. Additionally, collecting radar data alongside oral reports would help research efforts.

All three witnesses agreed that the 2019 classification guidelines for UAPs interferes with the federal government's ability to be transparent with the American people. They believe we need more transparency regarding UAPs and their potential implications on national security.

The second witness was Mr. Garrosh, also an F-18 pilot, who shared similar encounters during his time in service. Lastly, Commander Grush provided valuable insights into the security review process for UAP information. When questioned further about the most vivid sighting involving cube-like objects, Mr. Graves described how two fighter jets flew within 50 feet of one such object near midair - right at the entrance to their working area along the eastern seaboard. In response to another question regarding why he came forward on this issue, Mr. Garrosh stated that it was primarily because he wanted to help his colleagues who were still flying and dealing with these mysterious aerial phenomena. As an aviation safety officer trained by the Navy, he felt compelled to share his experiences out of duty and responsibility towards those facing similar threats.

Commander Grush also shared his reasons for coming forward: after being pestered multiple times by a friend, he eventually agreed to do so as "the one person [they] can't discredit" and would add credibility to The New York Times article. He emphasized that this town isn't made up entirely of people like them but rather individuals who keep this issue alive despite criticism and derogatory remarks.

The witnesses expressed gratitude for the public's support in keeping this topic alive and encouraged everyone watching to continue reporting UAP sightings if possible. Next, Ms. Tracy Torme spoke about her work on the television series "The X-Files" and her belief that there are extraterrestrial civilizations visiting Earth. She argued that governments should release classified information about UAPs to help advance human knowledge.

Mr. Christopher Mellon followed up by sharing his experience working at the Pentagon's Defense Intelligence Agency (DIA). He claimed that the government has collected thousands of reports of UAP sightings over many years but has failed to adequately investigate them due to bureaucratic obstacles and lack of funding.

Mr. Garash shared his perspective as a former intelligence officer who now works for the Department of Homeland Security. He emphasized the importance of collecting objective data through technology solutions and encouraged current and former military personnel to come forward if they have any relevant information.

The next panelist, Mr. Gimbel, discussed his work analyzing UAP data for the Office of Naval Intelligence (ONI) and the DIA. He argued that there is enough evidence to suggest that some UAPs are likely extraterrestrial in origin but stressed the need for more scientific study before drawing definitive conclusions.

Dr. Puthoff then spoke about her background in quantum physics and remote viewing research at Stanford Research Institute (SRI). She explained how these techniques could potentially be used to gather information about UAPs without direct physical contact or observation.

Finally, Ms. Torme returned to discuss the potential implications of disclosing classified information about UAPs. While acknowledging concerns over national security risks, she argued that releasing this information would ultimately benefit humanity by advancing our understanding of the universe and possibly leading to new technologies.

Throughout the discussion, several themes emerged: the need for further investigation into UAPs using science-based approaches; the importance of collecting objective data through technology solutions; and the potential benefits of government transparency regarding classified information on UAPs. The panelists also emphasized the value of collaboration between scientists, military personnel, intelligence agencies, and other stakeholders to advance our knowledge of these mysterious phenomena.
